interventions.Title: Sleep Hygiene Improvement
interventions.Description:
'- **Why it Helps**: Establishing a healthy sleep environment and routine sets the foundation for good sleep.
   - **What to Do**: Ensure your bedroom is conducive to sleep (quiet, dark, cool). Stick to a consistent sleep schedule.
   - **Example**: Go to bed and wake up at the same time every day, even on weekends.
interventions.extracted_value: Why is maintaining a consistent sleep schedule important to you?

interventions.Title: Stimulus Control
interventions.Description:
'- **Why it Helps**: Associates the bed with sleep, rather than wakefulness, reducing anxiety around bedtime.
   - **What to Do**: Use the bed only for sleep and intimacy; get out of bed if unable to sleep after 20 minutes.
   - **Example**: If you can't fall asleep, go to another room and engage in a quiet activity like reading until you're sleepy.
interventions.extracted_value:
Why do you think stimulus control can help with insomnia?


Describe a situation where you used stimulus control. What did you do?


How do you plan to use your bed only for sleep and intimacy?


What quiet activity will you engage in if you can't fall asleep?


How long will you stay out of bed if you can't fall asleep?


What are your goals for implementing stimulus control?

interventions.Title: Sleep Restriction
interventions.Description:
'- **Why it Helps**: Increases sleep efficiency by limiting time in bed to actual sleep time.
   - **What to Do**: Determine average sleep duration and limit time in bed to that amount, gradually increasing as sleep improves.
   - **Example**: If you average 5 hours of sleep, only spend 5.5 hours in bed. Adjust as sleep quality improves.
interventions.extracted_value:
How many hours did I sleep last night?


What time did I go to bed last night?


What time did I wake up this morning?


Did I feel tired before my bedtime? If so, why?


Did I feel sleepy when I went to bed? If not, what was I doing?


How did I feel during the day? Were there any periods of excessive daytime sleepiness?


Did I stick to my sleep window? If not, why?


What strategies can I use to improve my sleep efficiency?


Are there any changes I need to make to my sleep window for the next night?

interventions.Title: Cognitive Restructuring
interventions.Description:
'- **Why it Helps**: Addresses and modifies negative thoughts that can interfere with sleep.
   - **What to Do**: Identify and challenge negative or unrealistic thoughts about sleep and replace them with realistic ones.
   - **Example**: Replace "I'll never fall asleep" with "Even if it takes some time, I will eventually fall asleep."

interventions.Title: Relaxation Techniques
interventions.Description:
'- **Why it Helps**: Reduces physiological and mental arousal that can hinder sleep onset.
   - **What to Do**: Practice relaxation techniques such as deep breathing, progressive muscle relaxation, or meditation before bed.
   - **Example**: Spend 10 minutes doing deep breathing exercises as you lie in bed.
interventions.extracted_value:

How long did I spend practicing relaxation techniques?


How did I feel before starting the relaxation exercise?


How did I feel after completing the relaxation exercise?

How has my overall well-being changed since starting to practice relaxation techniques?

interventions.Title: Mindfulness Meditation
interventions.Description:
'- **Why it Helps**: Increases awareness of the present moment and reduces stress, which can improve sleep.
   - **What to Do**: Incorporate mindfulness meditation into your nighttime routine.
   - **Example**: Practice a guided body scan meditation before bedtime.

interventions.Title: Thought Journaling
interventions.Description:
'- **Why it Helps**: Writing down worries can reduce nighttime rumination and anxiety.
   - **What to Do**: Spend 10-15 minutes before bed writing down any worries and possible solutions.
   - **Example**: Use a journal to note things on your mind and create a plan for addressing them the next day.
interventions.extracted_value:
What am I worried about?


Is there a specific situation or event that triggered this worry?


What are the potential consequences of this worry?


What are some possible solutions or actions I can take to address this worry?


How can I break down this worry into smaller, manageable tasks?


What are some positive outcomes or benefits of addressing this worry?

interventions.Title: Paradoxical Intention
interventions.Description:
'- **Why it Helps**: Reduces pressure to fall asleep by instructing you to focus on staying awake.
   - **What to Do**: Instead of trying to fall asleep, focus on staying awake, which can ironically lead to falling asleep.
   - **Example**: Lie in bed and tell yourself to stay awake for as long as possible without using your phone or reading.
interventions.extracted_value:
Paradoxical Intention
What is my primary goal for this session?

How did I feel during the exercise? Was it challenging or manageable?


Did I notice any changes in my anxiety levels or sleep patterns? If so, describe them.


What insights or observations did I gain from this exercise?

interventions.Title: Sleep Diary
interventions.Description:
'- **Why it Helps**: Tracks patterns and behaviors that affect sleep, providing insights into what changes may be helpful.
   - **What to Do**: Record sleep patterns, including bedtime, wake time, and sleep quality each day.
   - **Example**: Use a template to record when you go to bed, how long it takes to fall asleep, and any nighttime awakenings.
interventions.extracted_value:
What time did you go to bed?


What time did you start trying to go to sleep?


How long did it take to fall asleep?

Did you engage in any relaxation techniques before bed? If so, which ones and how long did you practice them?


How did you feel when you woke up? (Scale: 1-10, where 1 is very tired and 10 is very refreshed)

interventions.Title: Limit Stimulant Intake
interventions.Description:
'- **Why it Helps**: Reducing caffeine and other stimulants decreases their impact on sleep quality and duration.
    - **What to Do**: Avoid caffeine, nicotine, and other stimulants at least 6 hours before bedtime.
    - **Example**: Switch to decaffeinated coffee or herbal tea in the afternoon and evening.

These CBT techniques aim to reframe thoughts about sleep and implement behavioral changes to facilitate better sleep patterns. By addressing both cognitive and behavioral factors, CBT for insomnia can effectively improve sleep quality and duration.
